docs.title: 🚀 PowerShell DevKit
docs.text: ![PowerShell](https://img.shields.io/badge/PowerShell-7%2B-blue.svg) ![License](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-green.svg) ![Architecture](https://img.shields.io/badge/Architecture-Component--Based-green.svg)  **A complete, enterprise-grade PowerShell development environment automation suite**  [Quick Start](getting-started/quick-start.md){ .md-button .md-button--primary } [View on GitHub](https://github.com/Tsabo/PowerShell-DevKit){ .md-button }

docs.title: 🏗️ Enterprise Architecture
docs.text:
• Component-Based Design - Modular, maintainable, and extensible
  • Intelligent Failure Recovery - Detailed logging with smart suggestions
  • Shared Component Library - Single source of truth for all scripts
  • Comprehensive Testing - Built-in validation and diagnostics

docs.title: 🎯 Smart Automation
docs.text:
• One-Command Setup - Complete environment in minutes
  • Automatic Updates - Keep everything current with Update.ps1
  • Dependency Management - Intelligent package manager integration
  • Failure Diagnostics - Advanced troubleshooting with actionable suggestions

docs.title: 🗂️ Modern Yazi Integration
docs.text:
• Native Package Management - Uses Yazi's built-in ya pkg system
  • Custom Plugin Fork - Includes bug-fixed githead plugin
  • Git-Based Configuration - Separate repository for easy sharing
  • SVG Support - Optional resvg integration via Scoop
  • Automatic Updates - Plugins and configuration stay current

docs.title: 🎨 Rich Terminal Experience
docs.text:
• oh-my-posh Themes - Beautiful, informative prompts
  • Git Integration - Visual git status and branch information
  • Smart Navigation - zoxide for intelligent directory jumping
  • Fuzzy Finding - Advanced file and history search

docs.title: Core Tools
docs.text:
• oh-my-posh - Prompt theme engine
  • Yazi - Modern terminal file manager
  • fzf - Fuzzy finder
  • zoxide - Smart directory navigation
  • Microsoft Edit - Modern text editor

docs.title: PowerShell Modules
docs.text:
• PSFzf - Fuzzy finding integration
  • Terminal-Icons - File/folder icons
  • F7History - Enhanced history search
  • posh-git - Git status in prompt

docs.title: Enhanced Yazi Ecosystem
docs.text:
• 7+ Optional Dependencies - FFmpeg, 7-Zip, jq, Poppler, fd, ripgrep, ImageMagick
  • Auto-installed Plugins - git, githead (custom fork)
  • Themes - flexoki-light, vscode-dark-plus

See all components →

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Start
docs.text:
# 1. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Tsabo/PowerShell-DevKit.git
cd PowerShell-DevKit

# 2. Run setup (as Administrator recommended)
.\Scripts\Setup.ps1

# 3. Reload your profile
. $PROFILE

Detailed installation guide →

docs.title: 💡 Why PowerShell DevKit?
docs.text:
Enterprise-Grade Quality

Built with production-ready practices: comprehensive error handling, detailed logging, intelligent recovery, and extensive testing.

Component-Based Architecture

Single source of truth for all components. Add once, available everywhere. Easy to extend and maintain.

Modern Tool Integration

Seamlessly integrates the best modern CLI tools: oh-my-posh, Yazi, fzf, zoxide, and more.

Continuous Updates

Built-in update mechanism keeps your entire environment current with minimal effort.

docs.title: 🤝 Contributing
docs.text:
Contributions are welcome! See our contributing guide to get started.

(Contributing guide coming soon)

docs.title: Building Documentation Locally
docs.text: This guide shows you how to build and preview the MkDocs documentation on your local machine.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.7 or higher
  • pip (Python package manager)

docs.title: 1. Install Python Dependencies
docs.text:
# Install from requirements file
pip install -r requirements.txt

Or install individually:

pip install mkdocs-material
pip install mkdocs-git-revision-date-localized-plugin

docs.title: Preview Locally
docs.text:
Start a local development server with live reload:

mkdocs serve

Then open your browser to: http://127.0.0.1:8000

The site will automatically reload when you save changes to any documentation file.

docs.title: Build Static Site
docs.text:
Generate the static HTML files:

mkdocs build

The generated site will be in the site/ directory.

docs.title: Clean Build
docs.text:
Remove the site/ directory and rebuild:

# Remove site directory
Remove-Item -Recurse -Force site -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

# Rebuild
mkdocs build

docs.title: Deploy to GitHub Pages
docs.text:
The documentation automatically deploys to GitHub Pages when you push to the master branch (via GitHub Actions).

To manually deploy:

mkdocs gh-deploy

This will: 1. Build the documentation 2. Push it to the gh-pages branch 3. GitHub Pages will serve it at https://tsabo.github.io/PowerShell-DevKit/

docs.text:
docs/
├── index.md                  # Home page
├── getting-started/

docs.title: Markdown Features
docs.text:
MkDocs Material supports:

  • Admonitions (notes, warnings, tips)
  • Code blocks with syntax highlighting
  • Tabs for alternative content
  • Tables
  • Task lists
  • Emojis

docs.title: Example Admonitions
docs.text:
!!! note
    This is a note

!!! warning
    This is a warning

!!! tip
    This is a tip

!!! example
    This is an example

docs.title: Example Code Blocks
docs.text:
```powershell
# PowerShell code
Get-ChildItem
```

```yaml
# YAML code
key: value
```

docs.title: Example Tabs
docs.text:
=== "Windows"
    Windows-specific content

=== "Linux"
    Linux-specific content

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
The MkDocs configuration is in mkdocs.yml at the project root.

Key settings: - site_name - Documentation title - theme - Theme settings (Material) - nav - Navigation structure - markdown_extensions - Enabled markdown features

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
If port 8000 is in use:

mkdocs serve -a localhost:8001

docs.title: Build Errors
docs.text: Check for: - Missing pages referenced in mkdocs.yml - Broken internal links - Invalid YAML in mkdocs.yml

docs.title: Live Reload Not Working
docs.text:
• Ensure you saved the file
  • Check the terminal for error messages
  • Try restarting the dev server

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• MkDocs Documentation
  • Material for MkDocs
  • Markdown Guide

docs.title: What is PowerShell DevKit?
docs.text: PowerShell DevKit is an enterprise-grade automation suite that sets up a complete PowerShell development environment with modern tools, themes, and configurations.

docs.title: Do I need to be an administrator?
docs.text: Administrator rights are recommended for the best experience, but most components will install with standard user permissions. Some features may require manual UAC approval.

docs.title: Will this work on PowerShell 5.1?
docs.text: The setup script will automatically install PowerShell 7+ for you if you're running Windows PowerShell 5.1. PowerShell 7+ is required for full functionality.

docs.title: Can I uninstall components later?
docs.text:
Yes! Each component can be uninstalled independently: 

# Uninstall via winget
winget uninstall oh-my-posh
winget uninstall yazi

# Uninstall PowerShell modules
Uninstall-Module PSFzf

docs.title: How long does installation take?
docs.text: Typically 5-10 minutes depending on your internet connection and whether components are already installed.

docs.title: Can I install on multiple machines?
docs.text: Yes! Clone the repository on each machine and run Setup.ps1. The setup is idempotent—it skips already-installed components.

docs.title: What if setup fails partway through?
docs.text: Simply re-run Setup.ps1. Already-installed components will be detected and skipped, and it will continue from where it failed.

docs.title: Can I customize what gets installed?
docs.text: Currently, you can skip optional components during setup.

docs.title: How do I update everything?
docs.text:
.\Scripts\Update.ps1

This updates all winget packages, PowerShell modules, and Yazi components.

docs.title: How do I customize my prompt?
docs.text: Edit the oh-my-posh theme files in Config/oh-my-posh/.

docs.title: How do I add my own PowerShell functions?
docs.text: Create them in PowerShell/CustomModules/ or PowerShell/CustomProfile.ps1.

docs.title: Can I use a different terminal?
docs.text: Yes, but Windows Terminal is recommended. The setup auto-configures Windows Terminal. Other terminals may require manual configuration.

docs.title: How do I launch Yazi?
docs.text:
Simply type yazi in PowerShell: 

yazi

docs.title: Yazi shortcuts aren't working
docs.text:
Make sure you've reloaded your profile: 

. $PROFILE

docs.title: How do I add more Yazi plugins?
docs.text:
# List available plugins
ya pkg list

# Add a plugin
ya pkg add "username/plugin-name"

docs.title: Can I use my own Yazi configuration?
docs.text: Yes! The setup clones the configuration from a git repository. You can: 1. Fork the yazi_config repository 2. Modify Components.psm1 to point to your fork 3. Customize the configuration in your fork

docs.title: Fonts look weird in my prompt
docs.text:
Install the CascadiaCode Nerd Font: 

oh-my-posh font install CascadiaCode

Then set it in Windows Terminal settings.

docs.title: winget commands aren't working
docs.text:
Ensure winget is installed: 

winget --version

If not installed, update Windows or install App Installer from Microsoft Store.

docs.title: Some modules failed to install
docs.text:
Trust the PowerShell Gallery: 

Set-PSRepository -Name PSGallery -InstallationPolicy Trusted

docs.title: Where are the logs?
docs.text: Setup logs are in .\Scripts\Logs\Setup_YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS.log.

docs.title: Where is my PowerShell profile?
docs.text:
# View profile location
$PROFILE

# Open profile
code $PROFILE

docs.title: How do I change my oh-my-posh theme?
docs.text:
Edit your profile ($PROFILE) and change the theme path: 

oh-my-posh init pwsh --config "path\to\your\theme.omp.json" | Invoke-Expression

docs.title: Can I sync my configuration across machines?
docs.text: Yes! The entire PowerShell-DevKit folder can be version-controlled. Custom modules and profiles are in separate directories that can be synced.

docs.title: How often should I run Update.ps1?
docs.text: Weekly or monthly is recommended, or whenever you want the latest versions of tools.

docs.title: Will updates break my customizations?
docs.text: No. Custom modules, custom profile, and Yazi local modifications are preserved during updates.

docs.title: Can I auto-update?
docs.text: You can schedule Update.ps1 with Windows Task Scheduler, but it's recommended to review updates manually.

docs.title: Can I contribute?
docs.text: Yes! Check the repository for contribution guidelines.

docs.title: How do I understand the architecture?
docs.text: The system uses a component-based architecture with orchestrator scripts (Setup.ps1, Test.ps1, Update.ps1) and a shared component definition module (Components.psm1).

docs.title: Can I add my own components?
docs.text: Yes! Components are defined in Scripts/Components.psm1 with properties like Name, Source, and custom installers.

docs.title: Is this compatible with WSL?
docs.text: The PowerShell DevKit is designed for Windows PowerShell. For WSL, you'd need to adapt it for Linux package managers and paths.

docs.title: Still have questions?
docs.text:
• Check the Troubleshooting Guide
  • Open an issue on GitHub
  • Review the full documentation

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common issues and their solutions.

docs.title: Execution Policy Error
docs.text:
Symptom: 

.\Scripts\Setup.ps1 : File cannot be loaded because running scripts is disabled on this system.

Solution: 

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser

docs.title: winget Not Found
docs.text:
Symptom: 

winget : The term 'winget' is not recognized

Solutions:

  1. Update Windows:
  2. Open Settings → Windows Update
  3. Install all available updates

  4. Restart your computer

  5. Install App Installer:

  6. Open Microsoft Store
  7. Search for "App Installer"

  8. Click "Get" or "Update"

  9. Manual Installation:

  10. Download from GitHub
  11. Install the .msixbundle file

docs.title: Module Installation Failed
docs.text:
Symptom: 

WARNING: Unable to resolve package source 'PSGallery'

Solution: 

# Trust PSGallery
Set-PSRepository -Name PSGallery -InstallationPolicy Trusted

# Re-run setup
.\Scripts\Setup.ps1

docs.title: Setup Hangs
docs.text:
Symptom: Setup appears frozen on a specific package installation.

Cause: Timeout protection should prevent this, but if it occurs:

Solution: 1. Wait for 60-second timeout 2. Press Ctrl+C to cancel 3. Check logs in .\Scripts\Logs\ 4. Re-run setup (already installed components will be skipped)

docs.title: oh-my-posh Not Showing Correctly
docs.text:
Symptom: Weird characters or boxes in prompt.

Solutions:

  1. Font Issue: 

    # Reinstall font
oh-my-posh font install CascadiaCode

  2. Terminal Font Settings:

  3. Open Windows Terminal settings
  4. Set font to "CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font Mono"
  5. Restart terminal

docs.title: Yazi Doesn't Start
docs.text:
Symptom: 

yazi : The term 'yazi' is not recognized

Solution: 

# Restart terminal to refresh PATH
# Or manually add to PATH
$env:PATH += ";$env:LOCALAPPDATA\Microsoft\WinGet\Links"

# Reload profile
. $PROFILE

docs.title: Git Status Not Showing in Prompt
docs.text:
Symptom: No git branch or status in prompt when in a git repository.

Solutions:

  1. Ensure posh-git is installed: 

    Get-Module -ListAvailable posh-git

  2. Reload profile: 

    . $PROFILE

  3. Check oh-my-posh theme:

  4. Ensure theme includes git segment

docs.title: Plugins Not Loading
docs.text:
Symptom: Yazi plugins don't appear to work.

Solution: 

# Check plugin installation
ya pkg list

# Reinstall plugins
ya pkg add "yazi-rs/plugins:git"
ya pkg add "Tsabo/githead"

docs.title: No File Previews
docs.text:
Symptom: Yazi doesn't show file previews.

Cause: Missing optional dependencies.

Solution: 

# Install all optional dependencies
Install-YaziOptionals

docs.title: Configuration Overwritten
docs.text:
Symptom: Custom Yazi configuration changes are lost.

Cause: Git pull overwrites local changes.

Prevention: The setup now detects local modifications and skips pulling updates.

Manual Update: 

cd $env:APPDATA\yazi
git stash
git pull
git stash pop

docs.title: Update Script Fails
docs.text:
Symptom: Update.ps1 reports errors.

Solution: 

# Update with detailed output
.\Scripts\Update.ps1 -Verbose

# Check specific component
.\Scripts\Test.ps1

docs.title: Modules Won't Update
docs.text:
Symptom: PowerShell modules show as outdated but won't update.

Solution: 

# Force update
Update-Module -Name PSFzf -Force
Update-Module -Name Terminal-Icons -Force
Update-Module -Name posh-git -Force

docs.title: Check Installation Status
docs.text:
# Run test script
.\Scripts\Test.ps1

# Check specific component
Get-Command oh-my-posh
Get-Command yazi
Get-Module -ListAvailable PSFzf

docs.title: View Setup Logs
docs.text:
# View latest log
Get-Content .\Scripts\Logs\Setup_*.log | Select-Object -Last 50

# Search for errors
Get-Content .\Scripts\Logs\Setup_*.log | Select-String "error|fail"

docs.title: Verify PATH
docs.text:
# Check if tools are in PATH
$env:PATH -split ';' | Where-Object { $_ -like '*winget*' -or $_ -like '*yazi*' }

docs.title: Check Profile Loading
docs.text:
# Verify profile exists
Test-Path $PROFILE

# Check profile content
Get-Content $PROFILE

# Reload profile
. $PROFILE

docs.title: Getting More Help
docs.text:
If you're still experiencing issues:

  1. Check Logs: Review .\Scripts\Logs\ for detailed error messages
  2. Run Tests: Execute .\Scripts\Test.ps1 for component status
  3. Clean Install: Remove installed components and re-run setup
  4. GitHub Issues: Open an issue with logs and error messages

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: See the FAQ for common questions.

docs.title: Component Overview
docs.text: PowerShell DevKit includes a carefully curated set of tools and components to create a powerful development environment.

docs.title: 🎯 Core Tools
docs.text:
Essential command-line tools that form the foundation of your environment.

Learn more about core tools →

docs.title: 📚 PowerShell Modules
docs.text:
PowerShell Gallery modules that enhance your shell experience.

Learn more about modules →

docs.title: 🎨 Yazi Ecosystem
docs.text:
Complete file manager with plugins, themes, and optional dependencies.

Learn more about Yazi →

docs.title: 🔧 Configuration
docs.text:
Profile, terminal settings, and theme configurations.

Learn more about configuration →

docs.title: oh-my-posh
docs.text:
Purpose: Prompt theme engine Source: winget Status: Required

A prompt theme engine that makes your terminal beautiful and informative.

(Detailed guide coming soon)

docs.title: Yazi
docs.text:
Purpose: Terminal file manager Source: winget Status: Required

Modern, blazing-fast terminal file manager with previews and plugins.

(Detailed guide coming soon)

docs.title: fzf
docs.text:
Purpose: Fuzzy finder Source: winget Status: Required

Command-line fuzzy finder for files, history, and more.

Common uses: - Ctrl+T - Fuzzy find files - Ctrl+R - Fuzzy find history - Alt+C - Fuzzy find directories

docs.title: zoxide
docs.text:
Purpose: Smart directory navigation Source: winget Status: Required

A smarter cd command that remembers your most-used directories.

Example: 

# Add bookmark (automatic)
cd C:\Projects\MyApp

# Jump from anywhere
z MyApp

docs.title: Microsoft Edit
docs.text:
Purpose: Modern text editor Source: winget Status: Required

Modern alternative to notepad.exe.

docs.title: PSFzf
docs.text:
Repository: PSGallery Status: Required

Integrates fzf into PowerShell with keyboard shortcuts.

docs.title: Terminal-Icons
docs.text:
Repository: PSGallery Status: Required

Adds file and folder icons to directory listings.

docs.title: F7History
docs.text:
Repository: PSGallery Status: Required

Enhanced history search with F7 key.

docs.title: posh-git
docs.text:
Repository: PSGallery Status: Required

Git status information in your prompt.

docs.title: PowerColorLS
docs.text:
Repository: PSGallery Status: Optional

Colorized directory listings.

docs.title: Windows Terminal Settings
docs.text:
• Location: Config/WindowsTerminal/settings.json
  • Deployed to: Windows Terminal config directory
  • Features: Font settings, color schemes, window configuration

(Detailed guide coming soon)

docs.title: PowerShell Profile
docs.text:
• Location: PowerShell/Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1
  • Deployed to: $PROFILE
  • Features: Module imports, custom functions, aliases

(Detailed guide coming soon)

docs.title: oh-my-posh Themes
docs.text:
• Location: Config/oh-my-posh/
  • Themes: paradox.omp.json, iterm2.omp.json
  • Features: Custom prompt layouts, git integration

(Detailed guide coming soon)

docs.title: Yazi Configuration
docs.text:
• Source: yazi_config repository
  • Location: %APPDATA%\yazi
  • Features: Key bindings, theme, plugins

(Detailed guide coming soon)

docs.title: gsudo
docs.text:
Purpose: Elevated permissions helper Status: Optional

Run commands with elevated permissions without opening a new window.

docs.title: Scoop + resvg
docs.text:
Purpose: SVG thumbnail support for Yazi Status: Optional

Enables SVG file previews in Yazi.

Installation: 

# Install Scoop
iwr -useb get.scoop.sh | iex

# Install resvg
scoop bucket add extras
scoop install resvg

docs.title: Component Dependencies
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[PowerShell 7+] --> B[oh-my-posh]
    A --> C[Yazi]
    A --> D[fzf]
    A --> E[zoxide]
    D --> F[PSFzf Module]
    B --> G[CascadiaCode Font]
    C --> H[Yazi Config Repo]
    C --> I[Optional Dependencies]
    C --> J[Plugins]
    C --> K[Themes]

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: For now, see: - Quick Start Guide → - Installation Guide → - Troubleshooting →

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: Complete step-by-step guide to installing PowerShell DevKit.

docs.title: Before You Begin
docs.text:
1. Review the Requirements
  2. Close all PowerShell windows (setup will reload profile automatically)
  3. Ensure you have internet connectivity

docs.title: Method 1: Automated Setup (Recommended)
docs.text: This is the easiest way to get started.

docs.title: Step 1: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
# Navigate to where you want to install
cd C:\Dev  # or your preferred location

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Tsabo/PowerShell-DevKit.git
cd PowerShell-DevKit

docs.title: Step 2: Run Setup Script
docs.text:
As Administrator (Recommended)As Standard User 
# Right-click PowerShell and "Run as Administrator"
cd C:\Dev\PowerShell-DevKit
.\Scripts\Setup.ps1

Benefits: - All components install successfully - Windows Terminal configured automatically - No UAC prompts during installation

.\Scripts\Setup.ps1

Limitations: - Some components may be skipped - May require manual UAC approval - Windows Terminal config might need manual copy

docs.title: Step 3: Verify Installation
docs.text:
# Run the test script
.\Scripts\Test.ps1

Expected output shows all components installed with ✓ marks.

docs.title: Method 2: Manual Installation
docs.text: If you prefer to install components individually:

docs.title: 1. Install Core Tools
docs.text:
# Install oh-my-posh
winget install JanDeDobbeleer.OhMyPosh

# Install Yazi
winget install sxyazi.yazi

# Install fzf
winget install junegunn.fzf

# Install zoxide
winget install ajeetdsouza.zoxide

docs.title: 2. Install PowerShell Modules
docs.text:
Install-Module -Name PSFzf -Scope CurrentUser
Install-Module -Name Terminal-Icons -Scope CurrentUser
Install-Module -Name F7History -Scope CurrentUser
Install-Module -Name posh-git -Scope CurrentUser

docs.title: 3. Deploy Configuration
docs.text:
# Run deployment scripts individually
.\Scripts\Deploy-Terminal.ps1
.\Scripts\Deploy-PowerShellProfile.ps1

docs.title: Reload Your Profile
docs.text:
# Apply the new configuration
. $PROFILE

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Run the test script to ensure everything is working:

.\Scripts\Test.ps1

docs.title: Install Optional Components
docs.text:
# Install Yazi optional dependencies
Install-YaziOptionals

# Install just plugins
Install-YaziOptionals -PluginsOnly

# Install just dependencies
Install-YaziOptionals -DependenciesOnly

docs.title: What the Setup Script Does
docs.text:
1. Prerequisites Check
  2. Validates PowerShell version
  3. Checks for winget availability

  4. Verifies internet connectivity

  5. Core Installation

  6. Installs oh-my-posh with CascadiaCode font
  7. Installs Yazi file manager
  8. Installs fzf, zoxide, and other tools

  9. Installs PowerShell modules from Gallery

  10. Configuration Deployment

  11. Copies Windows Terminal settings
  12. Deploys PowerShell profile
  13. Deploys oh-my-posh themes

  14. Clones Yazi configuration

  15. Yazi Ecosystem

  16. Installs optional dependencies (FFmpeg, 7-Zip, etc.)
  17. Installs Yazi plugins (git, githead)

  18. Sets up themes (flexoki-light, vscode-dark-plus)

  19. Verification

  20. Runs component tests
  21. Displays installation summary
  22. Shows any issues that need attention

docs.title: Progress Indicators
docs.text:
During installation, you'll see:

🔹 Installing oh-my-posh...
  → Checking if already installed...
  ✓ oh-my-posh installed successfully

🔹 Installing Yazi...
  → Installing Yazi...
  ✓ Yazi binary installed
  → Installing optional dependencies for enhanced functionality...
    → [1/7] Checking FFmpeg (for video thumbnails)...
      ✓ FFmpeg installed

docs.title: Timeout Protection
docs.text:
All package installations have built-in timeouts: - 15 seconds for checking if already installed - 60 seconds for package installation - 30 seconds for git operations

If any operation times out, it's skipped and installation continues.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Execution Policy Error

Error: cannot be loaded because running scripts is disabled

Solution: 

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser

winget Not Found

Error: winget: The term 'winget' is not recognized

Solution: - Update Windows to latest version - Install App Installer from Microsoft Store

Module Installation Failed

Error: Unable to install module from PSGallery

Solution: 

# Trust PSGallery
Set-PSRepository -Name PSGallery -InstallationPolicy Trusted

docs.title: Checking Logs
docs.text:
Setup logs are saved to .\Scripts\Logs\Setup_YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS.log

# View the most recent log
Get-Content .\Scripts\Logs\Setup_*.log | Select-Object -Last 50

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
• Check the Troubleshooting page
  • Review FAQ
  • Open an issue on GitHub

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Quick Start Guide - Get started using your new environment
  • Component Overview - Learn about installed tools

docs.title: Updating
docs.text:
After initial installation, keep everything up to date:

# Run the update script
.\Scripts\Update.ps1

This updates: - All winget packages - PowerShell modules - Yazi configuration - Yazi plugins and themes

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get your PowerShell development environment set up in under 5 minutes!

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• ✅ Windows 10/11 - Modern Windows version
  • ✅ PowerShell 7+ - Installed automatically if missing
  • ✅ Internet Connection - For downloading packages
  • ⚠️ Administrator Rights - Recommended for best results

New to PowerShell?

Don't worry! The setup script handles everything automatically, including installing PowerShell 7 if you don't have it.

docs.title: Step 1: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
# Clone to your preferred location
git clone https://github.com/Tsabo/PowerShell-DevKit.git
cd PowerShell-DevKit

docs.title: Step 2: Run Setup
docs.text:
Recommended (Administrator)Standard User 
# Run as Administrator for full installation
.\Scripts\Setup.ps1

# Most components will install, some may be skipped
.\Scripts\Setup.ps1

Execution Policy

If you get an execution policy error, run: 

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser

docs.title: Step 3: Reload Your Profile
docs.text:
# Apply the new configuration
. $PROFILE

docs.title: What Happens During Setup?
docs.text:
The setup script will:

  1. ✅ Check Prerequisites - Verify system requirements
  2. ✅ Install Core Tools - oh-my-posh, Yazi, fzf, zoxide, etc.
  3. ✅ Install PowerShell Modules - PSFzf, Terminal-Icons, posh-git, etc.
  4. ✅ Configure Environment - Deploy profiles, themes, and settings
  5. ✅ Install Yazi Ecosystem - Optional dependencies, plugins, and themes
  6. ✅ Verify Installation - Run tests and show results

Progress Feedback

The setup provides detailed progress information at every step, so you always know what's happening.

docs.title: Try Yazi File Manager
docs.text:
# Launch Yazi
yazi

Navigate with arrow keys, press q to quit.

docs.title: Test Fuzzy Finding
docs.text:
# Fuzzy find files
Ctrl+T

# Fuzzy find in history
Ctrl+R

docs.title: Use Smart Navigation
docs.text:
# Add a directory bookmark
z Projects

# Later, jump back from anywhere
z Proj

docs.title: Explore oh-my-posh Theme
docs.text: Your prompt now shows: - Current directory - Git branch and status - Execution time for commands - Error indicators

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• 📖 Explore all components
  • ❓ Troubleshooting guide

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check the FAQ
  • Review Troubleshooting
  • Open an issue on GitHub

docs.title: Requirements & Dependencies
docs.text: This page provides a comprehensive overview of what you need to run PowerShell DevKit.

docs.title: Operating System
docs.text:
• Windows 10 (version 1903 or later)
  • Windows 11 (all versions)
  • Windows Server 2019/2022

docs.title: PowerShell
docs.text:
• PowerShell 7.0+ (automatically installed if missing)
  • PowerShell Core 6.x also supported

PowerShell Auto-Install

If you're running Windows PowerShell 5.1, the setup will automatically download and install PowerShell 7 for you.

docs.title: Permissions
docs.text:
• Standard User - Most features will work
  • Administrator - Recommended for complete installation

docs.title: Disk Space
docs.text:
• Minimum: 500 MB
  • Recommended: 1 GB (includes all optional components)

docs.title: Network
docs.text:
• Internet Connection - Required for package downloads
  • GitHub Access - For repository cloning and updates

docs.title: Required Dependencies
docs.text: These are installed automatically by the setup script:

docs.title: Package Managers
docs.text: • winget - Windows Package Manager (built into Windows 10/11)

docs.title: Core Tools
docs.text: Tool Size Purpose oh-my-posh ~15 MB Prompt theming engine Yazi ~8 MB Terminal file manager fzf ~3 MB Fuzzy finder zoxide ~2 MB Smart directory navigation

docs.title: PowerShell Modules
docs.text: All installed from PowerShell Gallery: - PSFzf - Terminal-Icons - F7History - posh-git

docs.title: For Enhanced Features
docs.text: Component Purpose Installation gsudo Elevated permissions Optional during setup Microsoft Edit Text editor Installed by default

docs.title: For Yazi Enhanced Functionality
docs.text:
Component Purpose Size FFmpeg Video thumbnails ~80 MB 7-Zip Archive previews ~2 MB jq JSON processing ~3 MB Poppler PDF support ~15 MB fd Fast file search ~3 MB ripgrep Text search ~2 MB ImageMagick Image processing ~30 MB

Selective Installation

You can skip optional Yazi dependencies during setup and install them later with: 

Install-YaziOptionals

docs.title: For SVG Support in Yazi
docs.text:
# Optional: Install Scoop and resvg for SVG thumbnails
scoop bucket add extras
scoop install resvg

docs.title: Development Dependencies
docs.text: Only needed if you're contributing:

docs.title: For Documentation
docs.text:
pip install mkdocs-material
pip install mkdocs-git-revision-date-localized-plugin

docs.title: For Testing
docs.text: • PSScriptAnalyzer (installed automatically)

docs.title: Terminal Emulators
docs.text: Works best with: - ✅ Windows Terminal (Recommended, configured automatically) - ✅ Windows Terminal Preview - ⚠️ ConEmu (Some features may not work) - ⚠️ Console2 (Limited support) - ❌ cmd.exe (Not supported, use PowerShell)

docs.title: Font Requirements
docs.text: The setup installs CascadiaCode Nerd Font automatically, which includes: - Programming ligatures - Powerline symbols - Nerd Font icons - Box drawing characters

docs.title: Git
docs.text:
• Not required for basic functionality
  • Recommended for git status in prompt
  • Used for Yazi configuration updates

docs.title: Network Firewall Considerations
docs.text:
The setup needs to access: - winget.microsoft.com - Package downloads - github.com - Repository cloning - raw.githubusercontent.com - Raw file access - www.powershellgallery.com - Module downloads

Corporate Networks

If you're behind a corporate firewall, you may need to: - Configure proxy settings - Request firewall exceptions - Use internal package repositories

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Ready to install? Head to the Installation Guide.
